cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Solid recipe. A couple things from the comments: use Bourbon! Not Jameson! Also, this isn’t a “sweet” cocktail. It’s meant to taste like bourbon. Try making your own simple syrup and infuse some dried fruits. I use blueberry. Finally, step up your game with some amarena cherries for garnish.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: This IS the classic version, just be sure to use the highest end liquor you can afford. (I use Makers Mark). Having said that, it makes a very strong drink, so rather than water it down with Sprite or Seven Up, try dipping the rim of the glass in orange juice, then in sugar - then proceeding with the recipe. Some will call it heresy - I call it delicious!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Perfect!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious, except I muddled the fruit first in simple syrup, add ice, then whiskey! Garnish with another orange slice!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Yummy! I make my own maraschino cherries and put a teas or two of the juice in the drink. I also make my own simple syrup. Very easy !

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: While there are many ways to create this simple drink what to me is essential is to use a good rye rather than a bourbon.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Used Demerara sugar cubes instead of the simple syrup and 4 Roses yellow label bourbon. Very tasty and not too sweet.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Not a bad recipe at all. Ensure you are using the "good stuff" as others have mentioned. Makes a world of difference. I typically use a sugar cube and some water with bitters. Also make sure you get large ice cubes for this drink. They dont melt as fast and water it down. I would never use a full orange slice. This isnt a screwdriver. Instead a hint of orange goes a long way with a simple twist of the orange peel over the glass then put the twist in the drink. Also luxardo cherries are a MUCH better choice for this drink. A little pricey but well worth it. As an added bonus if you want this drink smoked, use wood chips on a safe surface, light them on fire with a blowtorch, then place your glass over the wood chips to catch the smoke. While the glass fills with smoke, make your old fashioned and transfer it in to the smoked glass.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Followed recipe. First time used a very old jar of bitters. I bought a new bottle and much better. Used bourbon.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: If you are not a whiskey lover this is not the drink for you the bitters and syrup (and cherry and or orange) are not used to cover up the flavor but rather to add to it. If you believe that a Jack and Coke is a cocktail then you probably should stay away from drinks like this. I prefer making this cocktail without the cherry and orange.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: My favorite! I always use a sugar cube and pour a little bitters and juice from the maraschino cherries jar over it before crushing it along the bottom of the glass.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: loved this recipe!! The only issue is finding the ingredients in a convenient place and correct proportions Would anyone be interested in having a cocktail kit sold in stores with the necessary ingredients?

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used my favs to make this, Bulleit rye whiskey, made my own simple syrup with brown sugar, Angostora bitters, Luxor cherries, twist the skin of a clementine to release the oils and shook it all in a clean jar then poured over an ice sphere. It's very smooth sip by sip. Put your orange slice in there with that cherry and go sit by the fire.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Good beginning. I prefer to add the bitters, raw sugar and club soda to the bottom. I add bourbon and the thick orange slice, then fill the glass with ice cubes. Dangerously good.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I like to muddle the orange, cherry, sugar with the bitters first, and then add the liquor. Stir and add the ice cubes and a splash of club soda to top it off!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I added some grenadine to make it a little sweeter. And sometimes some seltzer.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made this with angels envy and it was better than I expected

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I added a splash of apple cider and it was perfect.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Made with Jack Daniels Tennessee Honey, fantastic! Stronger whiskeys will obviously make it stronger - so for comparison i tried adding a splash of ginger ale - wonderful addition. For color I drizzled in a little cherry juice.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious! I used Jack Daniels and left out the orange.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: A great classic cocktail. I used dried stevia and I muddle the

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was my dad's favorite drink when he dined out or when company came. I always wondered as a child what the Angostura bitters were for and now I know.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very satisfying. I used caster sugar and it works out fine. Don't skip the cherry!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Hi! Y'all made me thirsty! Used what I had on hand. Brandy, brown sugar, "Cherries in Brandy" bought at mall during Holidays {and some of the juice}, squeeze lime and lemon juices, Brandy, and ice. Nummy! Had another sip after sitting a bit, even tastier. I think the Bing cherries make this particular one, plus brown sugar.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I am a bartender and I have never made an old fashion like this.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love muddle old fashions.When my kids were little and going wild my husband would come home and make the best muddle old fashion using CC.I go down south and very few bartenders don't know what I'm talking about so I give them the recipe.Mash the fruit real good,add a dash of bitters,a 1/2 tsp of sugar,the CC and the ice cubes.Wow it's great.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Wisconsin Style Brandy Old Fashion Sweet 1/2 to 1 teaspoon of sugar, four drops bitters, orange slice with out rind, and cherry in bottom of glass. Muddle. Add two Oz favorite brandy. Fill glass with crushed ice. Add splash of seven-up and stir. Garnish as desired. Yum

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Good recipe. I like it made with Scotch. Be sure to use "the good stuff!"

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: This sounds like a pretty standard old fashioned, and the way I used to make it. Now I use all fresh fruit, and it is the best ever. I combine several dashes of bitters, a fresh cherry (cut in half, remove bit, then squeeze some juice into glass and add remaining cherry). A slice of orange (a small amount if the juice is squeezed in, then twist the rind to get the oils and essence). Several ounces of bourbon (or rye, etc, but I love Makers) sugar/simple syrup (I prefer sugar in the raw or a cube, it will bring good flavor) add a splash of water and stir. You get good bourbon flavor, with just a touch of the sweet and the juice to cut it. If you are making something like an old fashioned you need to taste the bourbon, if you don't want to taste it go get a vodka red bull, or a wine cooler.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: For an added twist use a little splash of olive juice, if your into a sweet and sour taste.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I thought this was going to grow hair on my chest! This was so super strong!!! I bought some Jameson whiskey for a dinner recipe and had some leftover and decided to try a classic cocktail. This tasted like straight whiskey on ice. I tried to modify it by doubling and then tripeling the simple syrup, doubling the oranges and squeazing them, and then adding in a couple of splashes of the cherry juice from the jar as others suggested. It made it more palateable then, but it still tasted too strong to drink. I wish I wouldn't have spent the extra money now on the bottle of bitters now. It couldn't be tasted anyway. I don't know what to think? Maybe, I just don't like whiskey? Hmmm

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Amazing drink and my stand by selection. If Don Draper loves them, why can't you?

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: In Wisconsin, brandy or Whiskey old fashioneds are made at every bar. I prefer the brandy. Often the cherry/ies are muddled in the bottom of the glass. To simplify we use 7up/Sprite rather than water and simple syrup. Some people prefer using sour mix instead. Stores around here also sell Old Fashioned mix. Bottoms up.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'm a native Louisvillian and using any thing but Ky. bourbon is a travesty! Makers Mark is my choice. I like bitters and use about 6 good shakes. To sweeten it up use a small squirt of agave syrup. Swish it around the bottom of the glass, Add ice, 2 oz. Makers Mark. Garnish with maraschino cherry plus a little juice from the bottle and slice of orange. (May sqeeze a wedge of orange.) Be prepared for a second one!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: My favorite cocktail, but is prefer Southern Comfort with a splash of club soda

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: My father had one of these when he came home from work. When we do the same it is in his honor. I keep a jar of orange slices marinating in the simple syrup in the refrigerator for this drink. We use Ancient Age bourbon which is what he used. According to the reviewer in The New York Times Ancient Age is just as good as the top shelf brands. The aroma is so evocative of my dad's favorite drink and so 5:30ish.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: The brandy old fashion is THE drink of northern Wisconsin supper clubs.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: delish! i used club soda instead of water, instead for a little bit of fizz and doubled up on the orange slices.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delcious! Recommend Red Stag by Jim Beam. It is infused with Cherry already.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: Excellent and classic! It really makes so much difference when it's made from scratch. My only substitution: I used rye whiskey instead of bourbon. I've always preferred my Old Fashioned with rye, not sure why . . . maybe it's the slightly drier taste. Try it sometime!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was my late father-in-law's drink of choice. Definitely use "the good stuff" when making these and while you don't always need the orange slice just like the Manhattan the cherry is always necessary.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: It's a sweeter change from ice cubes. very enjoyable.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: this is the classic recipe. It is missing something though. You will need 2 orange slices & 2 cherries. When you put the sugar cube/simple syrup & bitters in the glass, also add one orange slice and one cherry. This all gets muddled (squished) together, topped with ice and then the whiskey. Garnish as directed. DELICIOUS!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: A classic cocktail. Good with any of the above mentioned spirits but also enjoyed with brandy as a twist. I prefer the rye old-fashioned.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is my favorite drink in the winter except I substitute marachino cherry juice for the simple syrup and brandy for the whiskey. I also squeeze an orange wedge and add sour such as 50/50 or Squirt. Delicious.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Classic Old Fashioned
cocktail_reviews.Review: To make it more palatable (for those who don't like straight booze) a splash of club soda or 7 up is great!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod

I know BARBARELLA107 thinks it's a basic cosmo, but I believe this drink came before the cosmo.... PLUS-- cosmos have Lime Juice & Triple Sec, which makes it sweeter... I love both so it doesn't matter to me!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was pretty good.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod
cocktail_reviews.Review: This has been my favorite drink all summer. I usually add a splash of seltzer at the end to fizz it up. Flavored seltzers add new flavor twists. I've even shaken it up with the different flavors of cranberry (cranraspberry is a favorite). Very refreshing during the heat of summer and what better way to get your healthy juices in? :)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod
cocktail_reviews.Review: my favorite! since i prefer sweeter drinks, i like to add a bit of grenadine syrup to it.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod
cocktail_reviews.Review: I like to drink this in the summer in a tall glass, squeezing the lime wedge (or two) into the glass and topping off with club soda. I usually double the alcohol as I like my drinks stronger.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod

At any rate whether you're like me and just call it Cranberry & Vodka or a little more sophisticated and call it a "Cape Cod" - Cheers!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Cape Cod
cocktail_reviews.Review: A classic... I use a tsp of lime juice and half a glass of cranberry with three shots of vodka.

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used the same ratios, but modified the ingredients…used Espolon Reposado and 3/4 oz Grand Marnier and 3/4 oz Patron Citronge as the spirits…and added a bar spoon and a half of agave syrup…and of course, kept the same ratio of fresh lime juice. I didn't realize how much alcohol is actually in just your dekuypers triple sec, so this will be a fun night. Would recommend doing what i did for more than one, may do it to watch the fight this weekend with the boys.

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita

cocktail_reviews.Name: The Perfect Margarita
cocktail_reviews.Review: Good proportions! I like it!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review:
For those who don't enjoy this drink some tips i've discovered. You can easily use margarita mix instead of lemon or even sour mix. I've found most pre made sour mixes are not made well and while margarita mix is arguably similar if not the same thing it does seem to make a difference. For the raspberry-flavored liqueur you really should use Chambord specifically. It's expensive but maybe start with the nips if you can find them but it makes a world of difference. Cheaper alternatives like razmataz do not have the specific flavor profile needed. Also, this could be me but it needs to be ice cold! if it gets warm in any way blegh. Pretty much this is a raspberry long island iced tea, easy to make and a punch in the face for sure.
Other than that if you don't like it then all good. We all have different tastes and can change any cocktail we want to fit it. This is the traditional recipe tho, play around a bit.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: I did everything right and also made my own fresh sour mix. I found this cocktail to have a little bit of a cough-medicine like aftertaste. My wife liked it even less. Probably wouldn't make it again

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Not that good....

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Chris and his beautiful wife have a gathering of friends every year in Summer. Pool,amazing food,a killer band best in Fox valley, and a full bar. I had the pleasure of bartending for a few years and this recipe they came across on a trip to NYC years ago. We would put it in a frozen drink machine and make it in large batches. So GOOD... plus perfect for the whole day and night poolside. I miss you all. Best group of people you could have had the opportunity to serve.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Pretty strong and expensive combination. The flavor wasn't that refreshing and in fact it reminded me of cough medicine.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made this for a group, so I multiplied the recipe by 12 in a pitcher. It's good as described, but some of the group thought it was too boozy (which.... duh). Some might want something to add bubbles with sprite or club soda.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: this was terrible, I don't know where I could've gone wrong but neither I, nor my husband could drink it :(

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is a nice drink. We don't stock gin (one bad college night...you get it), so I left it out. Our Chambord is circa a decade or so ago, so it may be even better w/fresh hootch. If you've got everything on hand, this is a nice cocktail to give a shake. Or two.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used Raspberry Pucker in this drink recipe only because that was all I had. To make it fizzy, I poured the shots over ice in a big glass, then filled it to the top with club soda. BOY, was this GOOD.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Grateful Dead Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very nice. We use Razz-Matazz for the raspberry flavor and we call these Purple hooters. Make them into shots or on the rocks. Sure to please. Thanks for the reminder. Will be knocking these back for monday night football soon....

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I had one of these at an outdoor bar in Frankenmuth, MI where it was called a Blue Bavarian. The flavor is a little questionable (not as good as Long Island Iced Tea), but it was the perfect drink for the occasion and we all had a great time. I would drink one again.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: The instructions could use improvement, a 1/2 jigger is 0.75 fl oz, many sites list the suggested volume as 0.5 oz per liqour which is probably better for most of you. Best all to the drunks who put in over 6 oz of booze in a drink.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: Would try flavored vodka next time and add more soda. Had a bit of an alcohol taste unlike a Long Island Iced Tea. But still has a heck of a punch!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: as a big fan of the Long Island Iced Tea, i had to try this one, and oh my god, i was not deceived. I didnt read the instructions properly, and the mix ended it in the blender with the ice, and to be honest, if i had to do it again, there is good chance that i'll do it the same way. NOW, i'm almost done my first glass and.... i'm already tipsy! sometime, you just wanna get tipsy and try to avoid the extra calories so we go for strong alcoolic beverage. Well this one is now on my favorite list. Hope this all makes sense... Hmmm blue motorcycle is a killer! I'd say it's probably a speed bike ;)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: i think this drink is fantastic, I love a good jigger juice

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'd suggest half the count (.75 ounce instead of 1.5 ounces) of liquor.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: Overall a great drink recipe

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have heard it called a blue motorcycle, but I have named it the Memory Eraser! Delish! But one too many and you may forget some of your night.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I know this drink as a Skylab Fallout. The common reason for ordering one is to have a Skylab Fallout Race where participants compete to be the first to finish the entire drink, the difficulty is that you must drink through the straw, so no chugging.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: It is interesting to see the different names for this. In Utah we call this an AMF, standard, every bar you go to. And it stands for Audios Mother F-er. They are delicious and dangerous haha!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was really good--nice change of pace from a Long Island Iced Teas!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: Was looking for blue drinks for my Superbowl party. This is ok but needs a bit of tweaking. Too much alcohol to amount of mixer for me and I love Long Islands. Increased the sour and Sprite and that helped. Pretty color blue though! Thanks.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This drink is nationionally known EVERYWHERE as an AMF (adios Mother) Amanda asked about a toyoko tea if u happen to read this again a tyoko tea is simply the same as everything here except use madori instead of the blue ceracaou sorry for the spelling :)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is my husbands favorite drink. We order them everytime we go out but now we can make them ourselves.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: Packs quite a punch and is surprisingly palatable! It definitely needs the lemon slice, and we were quite heavy with the sour mix and Sprite. Enjoy!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This recipe is fantastic! It combines nearly 8 oz. of 40 to 80 proof alcohols, with 2 oz. of soda (BTW, Earlier comment on soda-in-shaker combo impossibility, Nope! Works good.) I much prefer it the way it is written, but my wife loves this blended with a scoop of ice cream, instead of over ice. Good stuff!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love this drink! On the west coast and here in NM we call it an Adios, which is exactly what you can say if you've had one too many of these drinks! I will agree with an earlier review in regards to the soda and mixing it in the shaker. I usually make it by shaking the alcohol in a shaker and then topping it with the soda, sweet and sour and a cherry. Which is much how a Long Island is made...

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was delicious! It reminds me of the Tokyo Iced Tea (which I can't find anywhere on this site!!) It's all the same ingredients, but instead of Curacao use Midori and nix the carbonated cola. It's really yummy, and you can barely taste the alcohol! Before careful though, because it will knock you off your hiney!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: Overall a great drink recipe. If only I had a motorcycle.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: I found this drink in a restaurant when I went out to celebrate my divorce. I loved it then and continue to love it! WARNING....It goes down so smoothly you may not notice when you've had too much until it's too late!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: This had to be one of the worst drinks I have ever had. I had to change the amounts of the existing ingredients and add a few of my own to make it worth drinking. And, you can't put pop in a shaker and shake it! It explodes! So even the instructions were ridiculous. I would not recommend this drink to anyone.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: We used to sell these where I worked and they are awesome. Slightly sweeter than a Long Island. We called it an Electric Iced Tea.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: In Memphis this is called a Walk ME Down or Call me a Cab! That is exactly what it will do. It is a wonderful drink!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Blue Motorcycle
cocktail_reviews.Review: In VA, where I am living, these are known as blue motorcycles. I went to Vegas one year, where I was introduced to this drink, and they call them Black Opals. What ever you call them, they are delish and get you buzzed in a second.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Loved this recipe. Instead of putting the vermouth in mix I put in chilled glass and swirled around then dumped out. It was perfect. I did however put more olive juice in mine making it a little filthy rather than dirty.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This makes a nice martini, but I backed off the vodka. I mean, 6 oz for a drink that serves *allegedly* 1? Pulease! that would easily be enough for two generous drinks unless, of course, your bar serves martinis in margarita glasses So, having backed off the vodka, using slightly less vermouth and 8 small olives from a bottle that I'm trying to get rid of and about 1/2 oz of olive juice, it made a nice on the rocks drink.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: No changes it’s perfect!! Cheers!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I reduced the amount of vodka to 4 oz and used three blue cheese stuffed olive - this was a perfect martini for me! It filled my martini glass to the rim! So good - and effective!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I first tried this at a pool hall,and loved it, I now enjoy this occasionally with Skyy Vodka extra dirty, no vermouth,3 garlic stuffed olives,I will have to get some Dirty Sue Mix, Delicious

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Thank you so much for this recipe. We received two bottles of delicious Tito's Vodka as gifts. Tried this last night - fabulous - especially the reviewer who said to swish the vermouth -. Two batches made plenty for predinner drinks for both of us. Added some cocktail onions. The first exactly by the recipe, the second just swishing the vermouth in the chilled glasses. The left over "swished" vermouth went into the onion bottle to flavor them! So easy so good. We will enjoy these often

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: 6 ounces was a lot of vodka. I had them go 4 ounces and it taste puuuurrrrfect

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Superb! Lots of ice in the shaker and shake hard but not for long. Just about get frost bite of a stainless shaker! Use good quality queen olives (and brine). Always adhere to the odd number of olives philosophy. This bit was from my recently departed dad (who was a seasoned bartender). "Why's that, Dad?" "That's the tradition, Son"...

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I didn't have the proper set up as far as shaker & strainer, also smaller size of martini glasses. In the video it looked like SO much. I eyeballed it, cutting all ingredients in half. Made 2 small martinis, they were delicious. Will use again.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: No changes and will make it again.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I find that 6oz of vodka is a little too much for me. But all in all is is good!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: very simple, nice drink! enjoyed

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used Stirrings brand imported olive brind that I purchased at the liquor store instead of the brine from the olive jar. I think it tastes better. A little goes a long way too and I don't use quite as much brine as this recipe calls for. I have used other brands of bottled olive brine and to be honest, I th

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love a good Dirty Martini but 6 ounces of vodka is too much for this drink. 3oz is more than enough to fill the Martini glass

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: So delicious

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I don't mix the vermouth into the cocktail, rather splash the serving glass with the vermouth, give it a good swirl and then dump the excess.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: delicious!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Just added a dash more of olive juice.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Not a bad martini. I would recommend using a good vodka and dirty martini mix (such as dirty girl or Giuliano). I made it twice once as written and once with a olive mix. The martini with the olive mix tasted better than the one using the brine in my opinion.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: EASY PEASY, if you have the ingredients. I happen to have DRY VERMOUTH for basting Cornish Game Hen for one one, BOO! And PIMENTO OLIVES, a craving for moi! Plus, Grey Goose Vodka, in like, FOREVER. Didn't know what to do with it! Then, looked up Martini recipes and thought, OLIVES! YES! Saw this and WA LA! DIRTY MARTINI FOR ONE! I DID ADD A BIT MORE DIRTY TO MINE! LOVE OLIVES! GREAT RECIPE! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SHARING!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Flavor was pretty darn good but I didn’t taste as much “dirty” as I would have liked. So, of course, I just added a little more olive juice. I suppose this isn’t as much of a representation of the recipe,but I really didn’t feel much from drinking it.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Love it!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: In a pinch - forget the vermouth. But the better the grade of the olives and olive brine, the better it is. Try a mix of olives such as Kalamata, Castelvetrano, Manzanilla and Kalamata.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: my favorite martini

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I've been drinking these for years, it was FDR's favorite cocktail, I changed the pimento stuffed olive for a jalapeno stuffed olive and boy what a difference it makes. Gives it that extra little kick. I also use Dirty Martini Mix instead of the olive brine. Not as much salt.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great base recipe, although I did make a couple of changes. I used 1/2 oz. of Santa Barbara Co. Dirty Martini Mix and only 4.5 oz. of vodka and because I would like to be able to stay awake long enough to enjoy a few of these ;) But this is my first time making martinis and I don't think they could have turned out any better!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love the dirty martini...thank you for all the great suggestions, made my first vodka martini...success!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Lets try it with Gin as it's supposed to be then I'll give a fifth star!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: My husband always orders martinis when we go out. They've always tasted so harsh to me I've never considered making one for myself. Thanks to this recipe and Titos vodka that's changed! What a great mix of flavors. Followed the recipe exactly. Perfect!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Perfect recipe! Good vodka is key here. My favorite is Belvedere, but Ketal One works better with my budget. I'd stay away from Gray Goose with this recipe. Goose has an almost "minty" aftertaste, which is just weird with the olive flavor. Go easy with the Vermouth. Just a splash is all you need. Enjoy!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is the perfect martini recipe! I have tried others and they never seem to be perfect but this one is perfect! Yum!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is my drink of choice except I prefer Bombay Sapphire Gin instead of vodka. I love the taste so much I have to restrain myself from chugging it. Obviously I love the olive flavor, plus I love how the saltiness of the olive brine contrasts against the "perfumey" quality of the gin. Delicious.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: If you just want one or have a small glass, do a half batch. And they really do mean a dash of vermouth. So delicious!!!! Thanks!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I LOVE vodka martinis the only cocktail I drink actually. Just an added tip. NEVER SHAKE A MARTINI if you shake a martini with ice your left with a watered down drink! Always Stir!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: The tip about using olive juice instead of brine is VERY important.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'm obsessed with spicy stuff. Try using stoli jalapeño vodka and olives stuffed with garlic.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: One of my favorite cocktails.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Well I'm not a bartender like many of the reviewers are but I do drink my share of....well, everything!! I like a great dirty martini from time to time and almost always get them when I'm out at a restaurant. I decided to try one at home but checked online first to see what people had to say about making them. After several searches, this recipe seemed to be the best to me. I made it as stated in the recipe. After reading the reviews I opted to use the brine from my favorite olives since I'm addicted to them versus using the brine from quality olive jars. I use Goya brand olives with minced anchovies in a can from my local store. I like the saltiness and there is NO fishiness with these olives. The brine makes a fantastic mixer for this recipe. It may be because I'm now on round two but this is probably the smoothest dirty martini i've ever had. It is very important to use a high quality vodka and vermouth!! I do use a piece of cooked bacon as my swizzle stick (see photos) to increase the interest in this drink but I'm not sure that's necessary. The next time I make this, which will probably be over the weekend, I will be sure to get blue cheese stuffed olives with the bacon swizzle stick and the Goya brine. Happy sipping!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Whoa, 6 ounces of vodka. Where do you find a glass that big? I have what I thought was a big martini glass, and it only holds 4 ounces. I love vodka martinis and have made them with many kinds of vodka and many kinds of olives. If you want a simple, but potent, vodka martini, stick a bottle of Belvedere in the freezer for at least a couple of hours, or if you're on a budget use Stolichnaya (Stoli) - yes, I know Stoli isn't cheap. When you put the vodka in the freezer, stick a couple of martini glasses in there as well. To make the martini, place a few Manzanilla olives on a skewer in the frozen glass, add about a 1/2 teaspoon of olive juice, and fill the glass with the vodka from the freezer. It goes without saying, you need to like vodka to enjoy this drink, but if you do - this is one sweet way to drink it. BTW, since there is no ice to melt and water down the vodka, a couple of these goes along way. Before everyone says, why not just fill a glass with vodka and drink it? Well, that would make it a vodka shot, which is also good!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I like that this recipe called for 4 stuffed olives. I usually go with 3 but 4 is def better. I tend to like my vodka straight with just a splash of 3BAR olive juice. Right now I can only find it on amazon but I keep trying to convince the local pub to carry it.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: The ONLY way that I can truly enjoy this classic is with Ketel One vodka, no vermouth, blue-cheese stuffed olives and extra olive juice. I like mine FILTHY!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This definitely needs to be made with a good vodka. I tried it with Gordon's. It was like rubbing alcohol. I'm sure that with a Stoli's or Grey Goose, this would be awesome.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: YUMMY! I get the idea of coating the martini glass with vermouth - fantastic! could never get the proportion right. I now understand why bar supply stores sell those spritz bottles for the vermouth - you have to get it JUST right. And - btw - 6 ozs. vodka? LOVE IT.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Yummy! You can also try with blue cheese stuffed olives.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great drink - Even better if you use Jalapino stuffed olives and use that brine. Man talk about a great tasting Martini with a slight kick

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: No offense to the recipe. I do not like Vermouth. I like mine on the rocks. I freeze my glass, add the ice. I use Tito's vodka which is extremely smooth. Squeeze fresh lemon and Dirty Sue's olive juice, just a dash. I then add stuffed blue cheese olives. Stir it up and enjoy! That is my favorite Martini on the rocks.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great for those who like vodka with olives. I like both but not together. I agree with the bartenders that some jar brine is laced with preservatives so choose carefully. I like Gin with a lemon twist and these days I have to be very explicit when I instruct the bartenders or I find olives in my drink. I suppose the olive crowd has taken over :-)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: A sure winner. This is the way I've been making them, except I use blue cheese stuffed olives. DON'T use the brine from them, use regular olive brine! I would also go the extra step of stuffing your own olives, store bought blue cheese olives are horrible. Olive stuffers can be purchased at any tavern supply store and some high end liquor stores, definitely worth the purchase.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great recipe but whoa 7 oz. of alcohol in one martini, that's one big martini glass!! I love dirty martinis but I agree that Dirty Sue instead of regular olive brine is the trick to the perfect martini.Gotta be vodka for me though.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: So tastyyyyyyy, try it with garlic stuffed olives!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very good. I use olives stuffed with feta.. YUM!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Hola! My favorite Martini is dirty and bad! Half vodka and half gin, skip the vermouth! For a spicy treat I stuff hollow olives with wasabi. It's easy using the stuff in the tube. This goes down so fast I limit myself to one! Suldos Martini lovers.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: If you love olives (as much as I do) you will love dirty martinis. I've had about 7 of them since I first tried them (a week ago).

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is my favorite mixed drink, but I recommend that people try a wet gin version (4 oz gin, 2 oz vermouth) instead of a vodka martini. IMHO, vermouth doesn't pair well with vodka, which is why the "vodka martini" gets closer to a glass ov vodka every year, but vermouth tastes great with gin.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I should have read more reviews. If so I would have omitted the olive brine and looked for "Dirty Sue" brine or used Tabasco. Maybe this just wasn't for me. I'm a Vodka drinker but this didn't cut the mustard or....... olive.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I changed the recipe after reading a few reviews and to my personal preference. I used a shot glass and a half of dirty sue martini mix (in substitute of the olive juice), I used a cold martini glass, coated the glass with dry vermouth, combined the dirty sue and 6 ounzes of vodka ( I prefer Kettle One or Grey Goose for martinis) in a cocktail shaker with ice then poured it into the coated cold martini glass along with 3 big stuffed olives! Delicious and very potent!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'd never had a "dirty" martini until this past week and really enjoyed it..so much so, I went looking for this recipe on-line and this is great! To the "seasoned bartender" who gave the advice about coating the glass with the vermouth and discarding excess -- thank you!! While the vermouth does lend a definite layer of flavour,I have had other martinis where the vermouth was just too overpowering (and am actually never sure what a "dash" constitutes in ANY recipe!) Wonderful tip! As for the olive brine debate, I think if you use the brine from olives you enjoy for yourself and are pleased to set out for company on a tray -- that's perfectly fine -- it's all about personal tastebuds, right? The described portion was a bit much for me so I halved it -- but this will definitely become a regular before-Sunday-night-dinner-drink (as I relax in-between cooking and serving Sunday night dinner! LOL)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I started drinking these before there was a name to the drink! Hence my name on this website. However, this past weekend I went to a Martini Bar where they had a "dirty kick Martini". The kick was two drops of Tabasco! It was just enough of a kick to make you notice the tang. Give it a try! Cheers

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love this recipe and bartended for years making this same recipe in both a Gin or Vodka depending on the customer's preferred taste. We kicked it up a notch making the Dirty Gunslinger by using Gunslinger Olives and brine (Jalepeno stuffed Olives)...makes for a wonderful, possibly too wonderful, martini.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I like to spice it up with a little heat and add jalapeno stuffed olives and of course the juice from the same olive jar. For you sissies that say it may be too hot, give it a try, it's not as hot as you may think but gives a nice little bite and a kick of flavor. And you can always yank the jalapenos from the olives too.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: For me a good vodka, olive brine and olives stuffed with jalapeno pepper. WOW

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I came up with a new twist on the dirty martini. It's called a "Hot n Dirty". Using the bring from olives that have been packed with pepperchini's. So you get the salt from the olive brine and the hot from the peppers. Drink martini and eat the olives at the end for a hot finish!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: My favorite drink!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: a few pointers from a seasoned bartender: most bottled olive brine has a strange artificial taste. i recommend using straight olive juice from a jar of quality olives. the difference between a top shelf vodka or gin and a low end is enormous when drinking a martini. save the cheap stuff for mixed drinks! start with a chilled martini glass, pepto it with vermouth, pour out excess, and mix your liquor and olive juice in a cocktail shaker of ice until ice forms on the outside. strain, garnish, and enjoy. the perfect martin!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is a big honkin' martini. I am a Gray Goose fan, but it's pricey. I have found a good substitute with a Russian vodka - White Gold - at a lower price. Don't drink this on an empty stomach or you'll be thrown for a loop!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made one of these and that was all I needed. This is not for me. The flavor was a little strange.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Try this recipe with garlic stuffed olives! It is very good!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I love a substabtial martini and 6 ounces is substantial. The best way I have found to finish one off is to use jalapeno stuffed olives. Nice kick.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I usually drink Vodka martinis but Tanqueray was on sale today and it makes a killer dirty martini

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I adore dirty martinis, but even my olive hating friends love these. They just leave the olives for me to eat! A great variation for heat fans is the Hot and Dirty - add pickled jalapeno juice as well as olive juice.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Husband loves these dirty martinis, the "dirtier" the better.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Wow! Hank, one of the reasons I like Vodka over gin is the taste aspect. I love olives and the sourness of the brine is great even with gin. I use blue cheese stuffed olives for special dryness. Hard for me to slowly sip this one.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Wow...the olive brine does take some of the bite out of the gi..uhm...vodka. Perfect for when you are in the mood for olives! I loved this martini.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: Excellent!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'm drinking one right now, and it's awesome! Word of caution, the olive juice takes some of the bite out of the gin, making this go down very easy!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: NOT FOR DIETERS but really a very nice Martini, especially if you are craving something salty.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Dirty Martini
cocktail_reviews.Review: I heard someone on TV talking about this martini and they couldnt say enough good things about the "Dirty Martini". When I found this recipe,its the greatest.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is perfect. This is the REAL margarita! Easy to make and so delish!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: I think I can make it everyday

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: I think this would help me doing it everyday

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: It is pretty good-it is pretty strong so you won’t care after a bit.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Fun and different margarita martini. The tequila is the main flavor, but that's how it should be!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: Pity the poor Margarita. The original concoction was a relative of the Sidecar: brandy, Cointreau & lemon juice served in sugar rimmed glass. The Margarita substituted tequila, with lime and salt being the traditional accompaniments. Then the mongrelization began. When I came upon the Margarita in the 70’s, it had been reduced to cheap tequila, bar mix and a pound of ice to be processed in a blender: an adult Slurpee. Follow the above recipe as if your life depended on it. Use a quality tequila, Cointreau and fresh squeezed lime juice. Triple Sec has always been used by bars as a cheap substitute for Cointreau, but they don’t taste the same. As far as turnbot’s use of an eggwhite, you are on your own. A Margarita is a cocktail, not the breakfast of champions.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Margarita Cocktail
cocktail_reviews.Review: This recipe is not bad: my "perfect margarita" calls for only half an ounce of triple sec (as opposed to 1 once; that much will override the great tequila flavour). Speaking of tequila: your margarita will be as good as the tequila you buy! Avoid the "well-brand" tequilas: for an affordable yet tasty tequila, get Cazadores or El Jimedor reposado. I'm not a fan of "straight up" style margaritas, so I'll always have mine with lots of rocks (ice), or blended. If you want a really frothy, truly PERFECT margarita... Before shaking, throw in half an egg white into your shaker! You'll never go back - trust me!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: So, so good! Very warming. I did add 1 teaspoon vanilla for extra yum.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Simple yet rich and delicious. Great "holiday" treat. (any day ending in "Y" is a prefect "holiday" :) )

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: So this batter isn't *awful*, but I worry that a lot of people are rating it based on how it sounds, rather than how it is. I tried making it for myself and my wife exactly as the recipe shows, and tried using varying amounts of rum with both water and apple cider, and this recipe uses FAR too much powdered sugar. It tasted like I had just poured a bunch of powdered sugar in a mug with hot cider or water. It's a good base for a buttered rum batter - but definitely cut the powdered sugar by half, and add a bit of apple pie spice. It also lends very well to using a 50-50 mix of spiced & coconut rum.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Wow!! This is delicious. I’m in Australia and just had a 45C (113F) Christmas. So, I made mine cold; used 2T batter with gingerbread spiced rum and milk in the Bullet. Delicious! Dangerous! Definitely worthy of saving this recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: A very nice holiday drink. Doubled the amount of the batter the 2nd time because it was a little watery the first time I made it to test it before guests came. Garnished it with nutmeg on top and a cinnamon stick stirrer. This is a bit sweet for me but all my guests loved it which was the most important thing!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I was so excited to try this for a Christmas party and it just lacks all the goodness everyone says it is. I followed the recipe to the T. It needs more spice! I used the hot water...mistake. I had to double the batter in my drink to make it not so watery. I used a regular size coffee mug and I finally added whip cream and extra cinnamon and nutmeg to make it ok. But this will go good in my coffee in the morning- so not a total waste.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Its good but I added 1/2 gl. Of vanilla ice cream. Also I didn't melt the butter I softened it and added more cinnamon and vanilla. Made the biggest difference. Ive been making this since 1981

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Simple recipe to reproduce. Great flavor. My new Holiday go-to.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This so easy to make and YUMMY!!!! to drink. I added some allspice for a little extra yummy.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Excellent! Great flavor!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Decent recipe, key is use a premium ice cream. Makes all the difference.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious! I took someone else’s advice and used apple cider instead of water and it tasted just like an apple fritter! I also added another shot of Captain Morgan’s spiced rum than was called for which didn’t detract from the recipe. So delicious and helped me feel relaxed.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made this exactly as written; all I did was to cut down the amounts to a total of 20 servings. It is amazing -- so easy to make and so easy to prepare a cup or two at a time!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is the most delicious hot buttered recipe you will ever find.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: It turned out good. I had to use a whisk to get the butter to absorb into the sugar, and it took some pretty vigorous stirring. I used Captain Morgan Spiced Rum but I have used dark rum with other batters so I will try that next. Give this a try.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: All I can say it makes cold snowy nights something to look forward to

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'm not a hot buttered rum connoisseur, but this was pretty tasty. The difference is that the ratio is too weak, as others have said. Others doubled it, but I quadrupled the amount of batter and rum in the mug. If you want to play it safely, at least try a mug tripled.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: We were entertaining a small group and didn’t need the full recipe, so we prepared a half-batch of batter the night before and put it in freezer overnight. The next afternoon everything came out tasting great and was a highlight of the party. We used 2 Tbsp of batter with 1oz of Kraken spiced rum.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is one of the best hot buttered recipes I've tasted. If you enjoy sipping hot drinks, rum, whiskey or brandy during cold winter months, do yourself a favor and try this. The mixes you buy in the stores don't hold a candle to this yummy, buttery drink recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Oh my! Just made this for the holidays. It is absolutely delicious! I did not use the confectioners sugar as I thought it was perfect without it. Batch #2 in the pot. This time I may put in the confectioners sugar just to see. Anyway, yummy! Can't wait to serve it to family and friends!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used more than a tablespoon of the batter, closer to 2 or 3, and added whip cream on top and it was phenomenal.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I used my stand mixer! It was so much easier.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Why is it the simplest recipes are always the best? Heaven in a mug

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I added some rum flavoring and a little vanilla and it turned out wonderfully!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I added whipped cream on top.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious. Unless you're making this for a big group, I suggest quartering the recipe. For a fun twist, add a bit of ground ginger or use cookie butter ice cream instead of vanilla

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Good recipe, very sweet though. I Would cut the powdered sugar down by half. Also, no need to melt the butter down. I would cream the butter and sugar and all ingredients together in a mixer, then freeze.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: so good! i didnt have confection sugar, so subbed with white sugar (1/2 amt). mixed with some weak coffee, and topped with whipped cream- delish.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This batter is nothing thing less than amazing!!! The only change I made ,because I didn’t have a choice. was salted Carmel ice- cream for vanilla. I was only going to Aldis and they didn’t have a small container of vanilla. I couldn’t wait to try it until it was frozen so I used 4 TB of batter thinking that if it was frozen the tespoon would be a mounded and not flat!. I hope all my friends are ready to get this for Christmas!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: We enjoyed this recipe. I like to use twice the amount of mix in each mug. Next time, I will make half as much mix. It makes a lot. Ok for a party.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I discovered hot buttered rum on a chilly evening in a little bar in Alaska, and instantly loved the rich buttery flavor. The bartender wouldn’t share the recipe but only would tell me that the batter was made with ice cream. Well, I did some internet searching while I was still sitting there and found the recipe! I’ve been making it at home in Minnesota ever since!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made no changes. It is great.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I would give it 6 stars if I could. Make the full batch, you will go through it faster than you expect. YUM!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This recipe is good. I cut out the cup of confectioners sugar, it’s not needed, and I ended up adding a tablespoon of cinnamon and nutmeg instead of a teaspoon of each. I also added a teaspoon of allspice. Delish!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Really good, but measurements are a bit confusing and it made way too much.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Made me a fan of holiday drinks

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: No changes and yes.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is delicious! I filled several small mason jars and gave as gifts. The batter doesn’t freeze solid, so the glass jars are ok in the freezer.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I am serving it for Ladies luncheon if there is any left for them, it us so yummy. Thank you for the delicious recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious! And for a perfect 'no alcohol' option, we also add to hot apple cider.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I was looking for a hot buttered mix recipe similar to one I'd made in the past, and this one filled the bill nicely. I did reduce the amount of powdered sugar by about 1/3 and used pumpkin pie spice instead of cinnamon and nutmeg. This is a great holiday/cool weather drink that warms the cockles of your heart and puts a sweet taste on your lips. (I usually add an extra 1/2 to one ounce of rum per drink or a splash of butterscotch schnapps for good measure!)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is a great batter but!! Measurements of sugar needs to be in cups not pounds and when preparing use 2-1 measurements of milk to water- so Much richer as I substituted heavy cream For ice cream on 2nd batch

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I've made this for the last 3 years. It's great just like the recipe states or you can add more of parts you love... its turns out great no matter what... very hard recipe to mess up

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: OUTSTANDING!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Good, but you need to triple the mix and rum in a drink to make it taste right, wimpy and bland otherwise.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made this exactly as written and we love it ! It is perfect after coming in from shoveling snow. I made it when it started to get cold and we are still enjoying it !

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Sent the recipe to my Mom who made it ahead of my visit back East. Fantastic!! Creamy and yummy. Just used a white rum. Went down sooooo easy. Just realized we forgot the nutmeg but will add it next time. Will make a batch of my own soon. Recommended!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I like things sweet and rich, so I made mine with 2 heaping tablespoons batter per one ounce rum. This was a hit at Christmas!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This turned out great! I made several batches to give as gifts. Anyone who had it said it was the best hot buttered rum they’d ever had! FYI for our Christmas party we heated up a crockpot on low with the mixture and water (1 part mixture, 3 parts water) + add your own rum. What a hit! We refilled the crockpot 3 times!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is the best hot buttered rum batter recipe I've ever come across. The vanilla ice cream is a great substitute for vanilla extract and makes a nice creamy texture and flavor. I prefer to make it without the confectioner's sugar, because I prefer my hot buttered rum more spiced and less sweet; I also added allspice and ground clove for the aforementioned reason. For an awesome twist, we used Captain Morgan Jack-o-Blast; pumpkin spice rum. This recipe probably made enough to last us for at least six months. 10/10, will definitely make again.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is so delicious. I’ve made it twice now and it makes a LOT. Not sure if one tablespoon is really enough for one mug’s worth... maybe if you’re using cider it is... but not with water... or maybe just for me since I like it a little sweeter. With water I use a LOT more. This time I used a special our local dairy had for the Xmas season... Eggnog Ice Cream. Since eggnog has a lot of the same spices called for here it is fantastic!!! OMG. I’d say better than the vanilla. I almost left out the cinnamon and nutmeg but decided to stick it in after all. Could’ve left it out probably since the eggnog ice cream is so flavorful. It is so good. We take a thermos of this snowmobiling to keep us warm. It’s a hit!! Mixed up and put in the thermos it stays hot for hours. Perfect way to warm up. Thanks for this wonderful recipe!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made a few different version of hot buttered rum mix and this is by far my favorite. I also add a teaspoon of cloves and allspice to mine.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: batter taste good. however, i followed the recipe and used half of everything because i didn't need 100 servings. my batter came out much darker than in the video. anyone have an idea why?

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Everyone LOVED this recipe! I did follow some of the other reviewers and used a crockpot full of cider, rather than hot water, to finish the drink. Delicious!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have made a batter similar to this recipe. I have frozen the batter in a container two years ago and it still tastes great. I mix batter and milk together, heated then add rum. Yummy

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I made it with frozen yogurt, it was to die for. made it 3x.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great holiday drink! I like to add 3 big spoonfuls of batter per mug and a little bit more rum.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was horrible! It wasn't creamy at all. I was very disappointed. Very expensive to make too.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have been making this delight for 45 yrs! Mostly I have used dark brown sugar and putting the spices in each cup as you make it!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: The batter recipe is good as is. I would give it five stars with a few changes: When preparing the drink per the instructions it is a bit weak. I would either add less water or add a full shot of rum (1.5oz) and almost double the batter called for. I also prefer it with a bit more spices but that is a personal preference. I will definitely make this again although the recipe makes a TON and I won't need to until next year! :-)

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I was looking for this recipe for a while. Next time, I'll leave the spices out and mix them in to taste per cup. Nice, rich batter. Great for Christmas.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This turned out great, although it is very sweet. I don't usually measure ingredients by weight, so used about three cups of each of the sugars. When making it again, I might try to cut down on the sugar.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Love this recipe! It's very versatile and can be used as a drink or a topping. My husband enjoys adding scotch while I enjoy white rum. Delicious for cold winter nights!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I had this recipe a long time ago and was thrilled to find it here again! Absolutely THE BEST HB Rum recipe on the planet!! Very rich and creamy and I used Myer's Original Dark Rum with it. I did use 1.5 qt of vanilla bean ice cream because of all the sugar. Just depends on your taste....Love Love Love this!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is my families all time favorite during the holidays! It's so fluffy and creamy when the hot water and spiced rum is added....leaves a little cloud of fluffiness floating atop the mug.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I don't care about how "authentic" this recipe might be... it's delicious! I make 1/4 batch at a time to keep in the freezer through winter, and make 1/2 batch to break it out at get-togethers.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: always hits the spot!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I didn't make any changes in the recipe but I did and 2 - 3X the amount in my drink. I like a Hot buttered rum creamy and sweet. YUMMMM I love that I don't always have to add rum to it. Sometimes I just add hot water to the mix... YUMM

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: A creamy, hearty, sweet warm beverage, that you can customize by adding more or less batter to your mug.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Awesome¡!!!!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious! No changes.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Soo good!! Goes great in a nice hot cup of coffee too!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: DELICIOUS!!!! Honestly, I have eaten it right off the spoon ;) Store the extra in 1 or 2 cup freezer containers to give as gifts! I have used this recipe for a few years, but now that I am diabetic I am going to try to tweak it using SPLENDA, SPLENDA Brown Sugar and BREYER'S CARB SMART ice cream!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have made this for years. 2 things I do diffrent is use vanilla bean ice cream and add 2 table spoons of vanilla. Oh and I use Brandy instead.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: My mother in law gave me this recipe and I lost it. Thank you for posting it again. This is wonderful at any time of year. My entire family loved it.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I've been using store bought rum batter for years. First time making my own. I can't imagine this being any better. This is the perfect rum batter. I've used it with Captain Morgans, Mount Gay XO, and in my Starbucks Christmas blend coffee. Delicious!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Oh my gosh. This is the most delicious hot drink!! The only change I made was to decrease the nutmeg, but that is purely personal preference. I also use 2 Tbsp of mix to the 1 cup water and 1 for oz of spiced rum. Delicious!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I've tried a number of buttered rum batters, and this is the best that I've been able to find, period. No need to modify other than number of servings.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: So rich and creamy! Perfect treat at the end of a cold long day! I made this and put it in small mason jars as gifts! So fun!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Delicious!!! I used 2 T. of batter to 1.5 oz. of rum. It was creamy and perfect.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I've made this several times now, and it's amazing every time. As written, it's fabulous. My second batch I used eggnog ice cream instead of vanilla, and it was even better. I just made another batch where I cut out the step of softening the ice cream by just using a carton of eggnog in place of the ice cream. Even more amazing. Definitely make it as written the first time as a baseline, but then there's lots of room to experiment. If you find the final drink too sweet, just use a little less batter next time. Also, I prefer dark rum to spiced. I make my hot buttered rum with Kraken and it's like heaven in a mug.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very easy, and was the hit of our neighborhood party! I'll be making His again for little gifts.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I'm not sure what wrong but it didn't turn out although I followed the recipe without changes.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I really like this recipe, although I did change a few things. First I added more nutmeg, and also added cloves, which the recipe doesn't call for, and cut the powdered sugar in half. So delicious, basically Christmas Happiness in a cup.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very good. Much easier and more convenient than the one I used to make in the slow-cooker. Being able to make on-demand is important for preserving the alcohol and rum taste, as compared with having a prepared bowl already heated.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Great mix but be warned - it makes a HUGE amount!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have been making this recipe for several years and it is a winter staple in my house. You can mix it with Captain Morgan, apple cider or just plain apple juice - warm and delicious every time!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Maybe I should review this in the morning...B-) Amazing! I just told hubby "This is pretty good isn't it?" with a twinkle in his eyes as he looked into his mug, he smiled and simply stated, "I wasn't going to say anything. Didn't want this one to go to your head." That's his way of saying "well done." :-D

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: D-lish!!! Love it! Make it often and it is loved by all. I use it in hot apple cider, not just water, though.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: OK, tried this the first time last night and I can't get enough of it! Definitely double the recipe if using a good sized coffee cup. I used Captain Morgan's Spiced Rum and Crem Brule coffee creamer with hot water the first time. I tried it with hot coffee (without the rum) this morning, but now that it's 5:00 "somewhere"... Love this!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is a big hit for the holidays. I have found that using unsalted butter and fresh nutmeg makes or breaks the recipe. An acquaintance was impressed and asked for the recipe, but was disappointed. The only difference I could tell was that she used salted butter. This year I was using the remnants of a former years nutmeg, and that decreased the fragrant aroma. It is great in coffee as well!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: A friend gave me this same recipe but she does 2tsp each of cinnamon and nutmeg. I didn't have ice cream but I had vanilla bean frozen yogurt and it was wonderful. I used blue bunny brand with the green lid NOT the pink lid. And used Bacardi "oakheart" spiced rum!! Worth the calories!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Nice and creamy!!! You will enjoy this easy recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Boy, is this good stuff! I've never had anything like this, but it was highly recommended by gammaray (= a fellow buzzer. I halved the recipe and tried it with half the rum amount and totally without the rum. I really like it best without the rum. What a wonderful way to warm up on a chilly night. The mixture doesn't completely freeze, so it is very easy to serve. With half a recipe, I got two full 1 pound containers.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I was a little worried reading some of the more critical reviews that this was going to be too sweet. I kept going back and forth over less sugar or more butter but ultimately decided to follow the recipe exactly. I used cider instead of water, and Capt Morgan's and I loved it. It wasn't too sweet, had just enough rum to add flavor, but not so much you're gagging on the alcohol taste. I didn't care for nutmeg sprinkled on top, but I did love a dollop of whipped cream on it. Tomorrow I plan to try it with water and maybe whipped cream and cinnamon on top!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Way too sweet! Needs maybe some more spices, a dash of salt?

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: yummy yummy yum!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is really good! makes a large batch to get thru the season with. Yum!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very good. But I did get too much cinnamon and I think the sugar should be cut down in the recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I have made this several times. I use 2 scoops of batter, 2 shots of MEYERS rum in a large mug and then fill with hot water. Yummy!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: We've been making this in my family for years. I've never met anyone who didn't love it. It's just not the holidays without a nice warm mug of this deliciously decadent drink!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: The only reason I give this recipe 4 stars and not 5 is because it doesn't include ground clove and allspice. I just finished making this recipe and am enjoying a cup now, its excellent with White Christmas rum and brandy drink and I also added a drop of apple jack liquor to it. I really do suggest adding allspice and clove; gives it a little extra spice that's o so nice!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I am having some of this right now and it is awesome!! Made exactly as is and wouldn't change a thing!! Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I tried this exactly how the recipe is written and it was awesome! Then I made it with bourbon instead of rum and it just got better. The bourbon seemed to cut the sweetness a bit.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This was SOoooo good!!! I served it at a group camping trip along with other hot beverages and this just went right away! Didn't change a thing. Served it with Capt. Morgan's Spiced Rum. This was to die for.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I had never tasted hot buttered rum before and now I wish I hadn't....because it is so awesome! This is a great recipe and makes a ton. I will put a bit more spice in it next time and I may use a couple of packets of spiced cider mix in it (recommended by a British friend) but overall it was wonderful.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is amazing, I only make it for the Holidays because it is to tempting to have around. Can't get enough! You need to make it to taste. If it is too sweet just use less batter in the next one.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I just made this over my weekend for some holiday cheer while I was putting up my christmas tree and watching classic christmas movies. I have got to tell you that this drink is AMAZING! The butter did not seperate like some of the reviews claimed. And if it is too sweet just add some more rum :D I will be making this a christmas tradition for the years to come.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: I read a book where they drank "Hot Buttered Rum" and knew I had to try it. The book had a recipe but of course I don't have the book anymore. So glad I found this recipe. I picked this because of all the great reviews! I just made it and put it in the freezer. Although I haven't tried it yet in a drink, the batter was delicious! Can't wait!! Gotta go buy some spiced rum and apple cider (for the kids)! Thank You!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: This is almost exactly like my Mom's recipe. We added real vanilla beans and used french vanilla ice cream instead of using confectioners sugar. I like to added an extra pat of salted butter when I mix in the hot water. Also try mixing it over a carmel square. So yummy!!!!

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: Very Easy and good

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: just finish making this it is ABSOUTELY DELICIOUS!!!!thank you so much for sharing the recipe i make a batch of this starting around hallowen in time for the holidays,this will be my ONLY recipe from now on.i HIGHLY suggest making this recipe.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
cocktail_reviews.Review: So yummy, but in my family, either you loved it or hated it. I halved the recipe.. My only real complaint was the spices would sink to the bottom of the mug so the last few sips were pretty nasty.

cocktail_reviews.Name: Hot Buttered Rum Batter
